questions.text: Which of the following about trans-perineal template biopsies of the prostate (TPTBP) is FALSE?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above

Highyeild:

Transperineal template biopsies of the prostate : Transperineal template biopsies of the prostate (TPTBP) are increasingly used clinically and may replace TRUS-guided prostate biopsies as a first-line test . Currently, TPTBP is used to further evaluate men with a negative TRUS-guided prostate biopsy in whom the PSA trend remains suspicious or younger men for whom a diagnosis of low-risk prostate cancer has been made and in whom it is essential to exclude more significant disease in other parts of the prostate (most notably in the anterior aspects of the gland) not easily accessible via the transrectal route. TPTBP is usually performed under local anesthetic and has a much lower risk of sepsis than TRUS-guided biopsies.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. TPTBP have a much lower sepsis risk than TRUS biopsies Option: B. TPTBP is usually performed under local anesthetic Option: C. Typically, around 36 biopsies are obtained during TPTBP, including from anterior aspects of the prostate, which are impossible to sample during TRUS.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of TPTBP over TRUS?

options.label: C
options.text: Can be performed under local anesthesia

options.label: D
options.text: Can be used in TRUS-negative patients

questions.correct_answer: C. Can be performed under local anesthesia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Can be performed under local anesthesia

Highyeild:

Transperineal template biopsies of the prostate : Transperineal template biopsies of the prostate (TPTBP) are increasingly used clinically and may replace TRUS-guided prostate biopsies as a first-line test . Currently, TPTBP is used to further evaluate men with a negative TRUS-guided prostate biopsy in whom the PSA trend remains suspicious or younger men for whom a diagnosis of low-risk prostate cancer has been made and in whom it is essential to exclude more significant disease in other parts of the prostate (most notably in the anterior aspects of the gland) not easily accessible via the transrectal route. TPTBP is usually performed under local anesthetic and have a much lower risk of sepsis than TRUS-guided biopsies.

questions.text: PIRADS system uses?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

mpMRI Interpretation and reporting of mpMRI must be carried out following standardized scoring systems (such as Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System [PI-RADS] v.2)

Highyeild:

Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging mpMRI is an investigation to diagnose an early prostate cancer that might reduce overdiagnosis of insignificant prostate cancer. Here dynamic contrast is given and should have four sequences: T1-weighted imaging, T2-weighted imaging, diffusion-weighted imaging, and dynamic contrast-enhanced imaging and spectroscopic imaging. The accuracy of mpMRI in localizing and staging prostate cancer shows a high degree of variation between reporting radiologists. Interpretation and reporting of mpMRI must be carried out following standardized scoring systems (such as Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System [PI-RADS] v.2). A score of 3 or above is indicative of malignancy

questions.text: A 45-year- male presented to the OPD with complaints of increased frequency of micturition, nocturia, and dribbling of urine for one month. On examination penis, scrotum, and neurological examination are normal. Per rectal examination shows an enlarged prostate. Ultrasound shows benign hypertrophy of the prostate. In this regard, from which of the following does BPH arise?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transitional zone BPH arises from the transitional zone

Highyeild:

Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia : It occurs in men over 50; by age 60, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH. It is a common cause of significant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men and the most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men >70 years of age. Pathology : BPH affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees. BPH typically affects the submucous group of glands in the transitional zone , forming a nodular enlargement Effects / Consequences : No symptoms, no BOO No signs, but urodynamic evidence of BOO LUTS, no evidence of BOO LUTS and BOO Others (acute/chronic retention, haematuria, urinary infection, and stone formation) Investigations : Essential investigations Urine analysis by dipstick for blood, leukocyte esterase, glucose, and protein Urine culture for infection Serum creatinine Urinary flow rate and residual volume measurement Additional investigations PSA if indicated Pressure–for studies Treatment : Conservative measures include watchful waiting in conjunction with fluid manipulation (avoid fluid binge and late-night intake) and a reduction in caffeinated and alcoholic drinks Drug therapy is with α-blockers or, in men with a large prostate, a 5α-reductase inhibitor, or both; combination therapy has a better outcome in glands bigger than 35 g Interventional measures include transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which remains the gold standard ; consider HOLEP (holmium laser enucleation of the prostate), open/ robotic simple prostatectomy for large glands; new minimally invasive treatment options that are available to patients include prostate artery embolization (PAE), water vapor prostate treatment, prostatic urethral lift (Urolift) and water jet treatment (Aquablation)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Central zone is posterior to the urethral lumen and above the ejaculatory duct Option: C. Carcinoma arises from the peripheral zone Option: D. As the prostate grows, it eventually compresses the peripheral area into the false capsule and the appearance of the lateral lobe

questions.text: A 50-year- male complained of acute retention of urine and abdominal pain. On examination, the abdomen is distended, with hypogastric tenderness and palpable bladder. Catheterization done. Ultrasound shows benign prostatic hypertrophy. Which of the following is an indication for surgery in BPH?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Haematuria Acute retention, chronic retention with backflow changes [ B/L/l HUN], complication due to BOO, Haematuria, FR- < 10ml/sec, and postvoid residual urine > 100ml are indications for surgery in BPH.

Highyeild:

Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia : It occurs in men over 50; by age 60, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH. It is a common cause of significant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men and the most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men >70 years of age. Pathology : BPH affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees. BPH typically affects the submucous group of glands in the transitional zone , forming a nodular enlargement Effects / Consequences : No symptoms, no BOO No signs, but urodynamic evidence of BOO LUTS, no evidence of BOO LUTS and BOO Others (acute/chronic retention, haematuria, urinary infection, and stone formation) Investigations : Essential investigations Urine analysis by dipstick for blood, leukocyte esterase, glucose, and protein Urine culture for infection Serum creatinine Urinary flow rate and residual volume measurement Additional investigations PSA if indicated Pressure–for studies Treatment : Conservative measures include watchful waiting in conjunction with fluid manipulation (avoid fluid binge and late-night intake) and a reduction in caffeinated and alcoholic drinks Drug therapy is with α-blockers or, in men with a large prostate, a 5α-reductase inhibitor, or both; combination therapy has a better outcome in glands bigger than 35 g Interventional measures include transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which remains the gold standard ; consider HOLEP (holmium laser enucleation of the prostate), open/ robotic simple prostatectomy for large glands; new minimally invasive treatment options that are available to patients include prostate artery embolization (PAE), water vapor prostate treatment, prostatic urethral lift (Urolift) and water jet treatment (Aquablation)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Prostate volume is not a criterion for surgery Option: C. PVRU > 100ML is an indication for surgery Option: D. FLOW rate < 10ml/sec is an indication of surgery

questions.text: A 45-year male presented to OPD with complaints of increased frequency of micturition, nocturia, dribbling of urine, and urgency. On examination, abdominal soft, no organomegaly, no tenderness. Ultrasound showed benign prostatic hypertrophy. Which of the above is a voiding lower tract symptom?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dribbling of urine VOIDING LUT SYMPTOM- hesitancy, poor flow, intermittent stream, dribbling, the sensation of poor bladder emptying

Highyeild:

Urologists prefer the term LUTS and discourage using the descriptive time ‘prostatism.’ LUTS can be described as: Voiding: Hesitancy (worsened if the bladder is full); Poor flow (unimproved by straining) Intermittent stream – stops and starts; Dribbling (including after micturition); The sensation of poor bladder emptying; Episodes of relative retention Storage: Frequency Nocturia Urgency Urge incontinence; Nocturnal incontinence (enuresis) LUTS are usually assessed using scoring systems, which give a semi-objective measure of severity and may help evaluate the outcome of the therapy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, & D. Frequency, nocturia, nocturnal incontinence, urgency, and urge incontinence are storage LUTS

questions.text: A 45-year- male diagnosed with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent Transurethral resection of the prostate. which of the following is the irrigational fluid of choice in the postoperative period?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Normal saline Normal saline is an irrigational fluid of choice postoperatively and can be used in bipolar TURP. When used intraoperatively with monopolar, it dissociates and conducts current.

Highyeild:

Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia : It occurs in men over 50; by age 60, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH. It is a common cause of significant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men and the most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men >70 years of age. Pathology : BPH affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees. BPH typically affects the submucous group of glands in the transitional zone , forming a nodular enlargement Effects / Consequences : No symptoms, no BOO No signs, but urodynamic evidence of BOO LUTS, no evidence of BOO LUTS and BOO Others (acute/chronic retention, haematuria, urinary infection, and stone formation) Investigations : Essential investigations Urine analysis by dipstick for blood, leukocyte esterase, glucose, and protein Urine culture for infection Serum creatinine Urinary flow rate and residual volume measurement Additional investigations PSA if indicated Pressure–for studies Treatment : Conservative measures include watchful waiting in conjunction with fluid manipulation (avoid fluid binge and late-night intake) and a reduction in caffeinated and alcoholic drinks Drug therapy is with α-blockers or, in men with a large prostate, a 5α-reductase inhibitor, or both; combination therapy has a better outcome in glands bigger than 35 g Interventional measures include transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which remains the gold standard ; consider HOLEP (holmium laser enucleation of the prostate), open/ robotic simple prostatectomy for large glands; new minimally invasive treatment options that are available to patients include prostate artery embolization (PAE), water vapor prostate treatment, prostatic urethral lift (Urolift) and water jet treatment (Aquablation)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, & C. Glycine, distilled water, and mannitol are the irrigational fluid of choice in the intraoperative period.

questions.text: A 70-year- male presented with complaints of haematuria and dribbling of urine. on examination and further evaluation, ultrasound showed benign prostatic hypertrophy, prostate-specific antigen- 5ng/ml. The patient underwent transurethral resection of the prostate. Which of the following is the most common complication of TURP?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retrograde ejaculation Retrograde ejaculation is the most common and long-term complication following TURP. Occurs due to disruption to the bladder neck mechanism.

Highyeild:

Complications : Local Hemorrhage Perforation of the bladder/prostatic capsule Sepsis Incontinence Retrograde ejaculation and Erectile dysfunction Urethral Stricture Bladder neck contracture General Cardiovascular - Pulmonary atelectasis, pneumonia, myocardial infarction, congestive cardiac failure, and deep venous thrombosis Water Intoxication Retrograde ejaculation and Erectile dysfunction Men with prior good sexual function are less likely to have erectile dysfunction following BPH surgery, but retrograde ejaculation occurs commonly (>75%) because of disruption to the bladder-neck mechanism; occasionally, anejaculation can occur as a result of a disorder of the ejaculatory ducts. This should be discussed with all men before the surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Bleeding is the most common immediate postoperative complication. Option: C. Bacteraemia is common in men with sterile urine and occurs in over 50% of men with infected urine, prolonged catheterization, or chronic retention. This happens in these patients shortly after surgery or when the catheter is removed. Option: D. Water absorption into circulation during TURP can lead to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatremia, and hemolysis. Treated consist of fluid restriction.

questions.text: A 45year male presented to OPD with nocturia, increased frequency of micturition, lower abdominal pain, and haematuria. The abdomen is soft on examination, with no tenderness, guarding, rigidity, or organomegaly. Ultrasound shows vesicular calculi with benign prostatic hypertrophy. Which of the following is an indication of open prostatectomy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above INDICATIONS FOR OPEN PROSTATECTOMY ARE Prostate weight .75gm Bladder diverticulum Large bladder calculi Orthopedic deformity Urethral stricture Previous hypospadias repair

Highyeild:

Prostatectomy : Approaches : Transurethrally (TURP) Retropubically(RPP) Through the bladder(transversally - TVP) From the perineum Transurethral Prostate Surgery : TURP remains the most commonly performed procedure for the surgical correction of BOO Strips of tissue are cut from the bladder neck down to the level of the verumontanum. Cutting is performed by a high-frequency diathermy current, which is applied across a loop mounted on the hand-held trigger of the resectoscope. Coagulation of bleeding points can be accurately achieved. The ‘chips’ of the prostate are then removed from the bladder using an Ellik evacuator. Resection proceeds at 1 g/minute in experienced hands. Following TURP, careful hemostasis is performed. A three-way, self-retaining catheter rinsed with isotonic saline is introduced into the bladder to prevent further bleeding from forming blood clots. Irrigation is continued until the out ow is pale pink, and the catheter is usually removed on the second or third postoperative day Complications : Local Hemorrhage Perforation of the bladder/prostatic capsule Sepsis Incontinence Retrograde ejaculation and Erectile dysfunction Urethral Stricture Bladder neck contracture General Cardiovascular - Pulmonary atelectasis, pneumonia, myocardial infarction, congestive cardiac failure, and deep venous thrombosis Water Intoxication

questions.text: A 50 Year male known case of benign hypertrophy underwent transurethral resection of the prostate. The postoperative period was uneventful. The patient came three months later with complaints of dribbling of urine and increased frequency. In this regard which of the following is the most common cause of delayed BOO following TURP?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bladder neck stenosis Dense fibrotic stenosis of the bladder neck occurs following overaggressive resection of the small prostate. It is the most common cause of delayed BOO following TURP.

Highyeild:

Bladder Outlet Obstruction: This is a urodynamic concept based on the combination of low flow rates in the presence of high voiding pressures It can be diagnosed definitively only by pressure–flow studies. This is because symptoms are relatively non-specific and can result from detrusor instability, neurological dysfunction, and weak bladder contraction. Causes : BPH Bladder neck stenosis Bladder neck dyssynergia or functional bladder neck obstruction Bladder neck hypertrophy prostate cancer urethral stricture available block due to neuropathic conditions Primary Effects: Urinary Flow rates decrease Voiding pressure increase Long-Term Effects: Irritable Bladder Decompensated Bladder Complications: Acute or chronic retention of urine Impaired bladder emptying Hematuria

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Stricture is secondary to prolonged catheterization, unnecessary large instruments, and clumsy instrumentation. The most common site is at fossa navicularis Option: C. It is an immediate or intraoperative complication of TURP.

Extraedge:

Marion described a series of cases in which muscular hypertrophy of the internal sphincter in a young person had resulted in the development of a vesical diverticulum or hydronephrosis (Marion’s disease or ‘prostatism sans prostate’)

questions.text: A 68-year- male came with complaints of increased frequency of micturition, nocturia, and poor stream. The abdomen is soft on examination, with no organomegaly, tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. Per rectal examination shows the posterior surface of irregular, hard prostate. Prostate-specific antigen 1000 ng/ml. Which of the following statements is correct regarding ca prostate?

options.label: A
options.text: Ca prostate arises from the transitional zone

options.label: B
options.text: Most typical type is squamous cell carcinoma

options.label: C
options.text: Ca prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of > 65 years

questions.correct_answer: C. Ca prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of > 65 years
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ca prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of > 65 years CA Prostate: Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years Carcinoma of the prostate usually originates in the peripheral zone of the prostate, so ‘prostatectomy’ for benign enlargement of the gland confers no protection from subsequent carcinoma.

Highyeild:

C A Prostate: Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years Carcinoma of the prostate usually originates in the peripheral zone of the prostate, so ‘prostatectomy’ for benign enlargement of the gland confers no protection from subsequent carcinoma. Screening : The results of several large-scale randomized clinical trials evaluating the role of PSA screening for prostate cancer suggest that, at present, screening the entire population with serum PSA is not cost-effective as a large number of men must be screened, biopsied and treated to prevent each death from prostate cancer Metastasis : Local Spread Spread by the bloodstream Lymphatic Spread Clinical Features: BOO pelvic pain and haematuria bone pain, malaise, ‘arthritis,’ anemia, or pancytopenia renal failure locally advanced disease or even asymptomatic metastases, which may be found incidentally on the investigation of other symptoms Investigations : Rectal Examination mpMRI Prostatic Biopsy General Blood test and Liver Function Test Prostate Specific Antigen Cross-Sectional Imaging with MRI and Transrectal Ultrasound Bone Scan PSMA Treatment : Treatment options for prostate cancer depend on the stage of disease, the life expectancy of the patient, and the patient's preference PSA, DRE, and biopsy Gleason grade are used to predict pathological stage Localized cancers can be treated by radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy, and active monitoring (surveillance) Treatment of advanced disease is comforting, and hormone ablation remains the first-line therapy; once it starts failing, chemotherapy is used with short-term success

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Ca prostate arises from the Peripheral zone, and BPH arises from the transitional zone. Option: B. The most common type is adenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 50-year- male came with complaints of dribbling of urine, nocturia, and poor stream. known smoker and alcoholic for 40 years. On examination, BMI-35kg/meter square, the abdomen is soft, with no organomegaly, tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. Per rectal examination, it shows the posterior surface of irregular, hard prostate. Which of the following suggests a high chance of prostate cancer on PSA analysis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

LOW-FREE PSA LOWER THE FREE PSA HIGHER THE CHANCES OF CA PROSTATE

Highyeild:

PSA is a glycoprotein produced by prostatic epithelial cells. Altered prostate architecture in conditions such as BPH, prostatitis, and prostate cancer allows PSA to enter the bloodstream and be detected by a blood test. The commonly used PSA assays measure the total PSA (tPSA) amount. PSA levels can be influenced by certain drugs, most notably 5α-reductase inhibitors used to treat men with LUTS, but also by aspirin, statins, and thiazide diuretics. A recent UTI can significantly influence the PSA test, and the true PSA level only returns to baseline six weeks after eradication of infection . PSA in CA Prostate: It is good at following the course of the advanced disease but lacks sensitivity and specificity in diagnosing early localized prostate cancer. Nevertheless, a PSA >10 ng/mL finding suggests cancer, and > 35 ng/mL is almost diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer in the absence of active urinary tract infection. A decrease in PSA to the normal range following hormonal ablation is a good prognostic sign. Following radical prostatectomy, the serum PSA should fall to undetectable levels (the limit for detection for modern supersensitive assays is <0.03 ng/mL).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Higher The Prostate Specific Antigen Density, Higher The Chances Of Cancer Option: C. Higher The Prostate Health Index, The Higher The Chances Of Cancer

Extraedge:

PSA Derivatives: fPSA - free PSA cPSA - complexed PSA f/tPSA - free/total PSA ratio Findings : Since BPH tissue within the prostate also contributes to tPSA, PSA density (PSAD) factors in the volume of the prostate by dividing tPSA by prostate volume. A high PSAD increases the likelihood that the elevated PSA is due to malignancy and not the large gland alone. PSA kinetics involves measuring the rate of change of various forms of PSA based on the premise that a rapid increase or modification may be more predictive of cancer. PSA velocity is the annual absolute increase in tPSA; a value >0.75 ng/mL per year compared with baseline has been considered suspicious. PSA doubling time is the number of months for a baseline PSA to double .

questions.text: A 50-year- male complained of increased frequency of micturition, nocturia, and poor stream. known smoker for 30 years. On examination, the abdomen is soft, with no organomegaly, no tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. Per rectal examination, it shows the posterior surface is irregular, hard, and a nodular prostate. Prostate-specific antigen is 500ng/ml. the surgeon plans to do TRUS guided biopsy. Which of the following is an indication for TRUS guided prostate biopsy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abnormal digital rectal examination Indications for biopsy are - abnormal DRE, PSA > 3ng/ml, PSA velocity > 0.35ng/ml, Free PSA < 10%, Prostate health index > 35.

Highyeild:

Common Investigations: Investigations : Rectal Examination mpMRI Prostatic Biopsy General Blood test and Liver Function Test Prostate Specific Antigen Cross-Sectional Imaging with MRI and Transrectal Ultrasound Bone Scan PSMA Prostatic Biopsy: If there is suspicion of prostate cancer, because of local findings, a raised PSA or metastatic disease, then a prostate biopsy using an automated gun under TRUS guidance is recommended This is usually performed transrectally, although increasingly the transperineal approach is being used. The Broad-spectrum antibiotic cover is given to all patients to reduce the incidence of sepsis, which is greater with transrectal than with transperineal biopsy. Transperineal biopsy usually involves sedation or general anesthetic, while transrectal biopsy can be performed under local anesthetic. Increasingly, areas appearing suspicious for prostate cancer on mpMRI can be targeted for biopsy to increase the diagnostic yield. TRUS scanning can also be used to stage prostate cancer. Locally extensive disease (T2) can be diagnosed with increased sensitivity by TRUS compared with the rectal examination, but many tumors will still be missed. This problem remains a real one in screening for early prostate cancer; In comparison with breast cancer, with mammography detecting 70–80% of tumors, TRUS plus rectal examination and measurement of PSA will detect only 30–50% of cancers that are known to be present on autopsy studies (although it may detect the larger, more significant cancers).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. PSA velocity > 0.35ng/ml is an indication Option: C. Free PSA < 10% is an indication Option: D. Prostate health index > 35

Extraedge:

Nowadays, fusion biopsy is becoming popular ; this is where mpMRI and TRUS images are fused with the help of software and a biopsy is taken very accurately from the index lesion.

questions.text: A 60-year- male came with complaints of increased frequency of micturition, nocturia, and poor stream. known smoker for 40 years. On examination abdomen is soft, with no organomegaly, no tenderness, guarding or rigidity Per rectal examination, it shows the posterior surface is irregular, hard, and a nodular prostate. Prostate-specific antigen is 50ng/ml. the surgeon performs a transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy. After one week, a patient comes to the surgeon with an HPE report suggesting it to be adenocarcinoma of the prostate. What is the investigation of choice for CA prostate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TRUS guided BIOPSY TRUS guided BIOPSY is the IOC for ca prostate, and it also helps to confirm the diagnosis

Highyeild:

Common Investigations: Investigations : Rectal Examination mpMRI Prostatic Biopsy General Blood test and Liver Function Test Prostate Specific Antigen Cross-Sectional Imaging with MRI and Transrectal Ultrasound Bone Scan PSMA Prostatic Biopsy: If there is suspicion of prostate cancer, because of local findings, a raised PSA or metastatic disease, then a prostate biopsy using an automated gun under TRUS guidance is recommended This is usually performed transrectally, although increasingly the transperineal approach is being used. The broad-spectrum antibiotic cover is given to all patients to reduce the incidence of sepsis, which is greater with transrectal than with transperineal biopsy. Transperineal biopsy usually involves sedation or general anaesthetic, while transrectal biopsy can be performed under local anaesthetic. Increasingly, areas appearing suspicious for prostate cancer on mpMRI can be targeted for biopsy to increase the diagnostic yield. TRUS scanning can also be used to stage prostate cancer. Locally extensive disease (T2) can be diagnosed with increased sensitivity by TRUS compared with the rectal examination, but many tumours will still be missed. This problem remains a real one in screening for early prostate cancer; In comparison with breast cancer, with mammography detecting 70–80% of tumours, TRUS plus rectal examination and measurement of PSA will detect only 30–50% of cancers that are known to be present on autopsy studies (although it may detect the larger, more significant cancers).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. MRI is the IOC to stage ca prostate Option: C. CT is used to detect bone metastasis Option: D. Ultrasound is used to take a biopsy of prostate

Extraedge:

Nowadays, fusion biopsy is becoming popular ; this is where mpMRI and TRUS images are fused with the help of software and a biopsy is taken very accurately from the index lesion.

questions.text: A 70-year- male complained of dribbling of urine, nocturia, and poor stream. He also complains of low back aches. known smoker for 40 years. On examination, the abdomen is soft, with no organomegaly, tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. Per rectal examination, the prostate is irregular, hard, and nodular. , X-ray of the lumbar spine shows an osteoblastic lesion. Prostate-specific antigen is 500ng/ml. Regarding metastasis of CA prostate, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Blood spread is more common than lymphatic spread

options.label: B
options.text: Breast cancer is the most common site of origin for skeletal metastasis

options.label: C
options.text: Bone metastasis may be osteoblastic or osteolytic lesion

options.label: D
options.text: Skull is the most common site of bone metastasis

questions.correct_answer: C. Bone metastasis may be osteoblastic or osteolytic lesion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bone metastasis may be osteoblastic or osteolytic lesion Bony metastasis can be both osteoblastic and osteolytic in ca prostate but more osteoblastic

Highyeild:

Metastasis : Local Spread Locally advanced tumors tend to grow upwards to involve the seminal vesicles, the bladder neck and trigone and, later, the tumors tend to spread distally to involve the distal sphincter mechanism. Further upward extension obstructs the lower end of one or both ureters, with obstruction of both resulting in anuria. The rectum may become stenosed by tumor-infiltrating around it, but direct involvement is rare Spread by the bloodstream Spread by the bloodstream occurs particularly to the bone; indeed, the prostate is the most common site of origin for skeletal metastases, followed in turn by the breast, the kidney, the bronchus, and the thyroid gland. The bones most frequently involved by prostate carcinoma are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae. The femoral head, ribcage, and skull are other common sites Lymphatic Spread Lymphatic spread may occur via (i) lymphatic vessels passing to the obturator fossa or along the sides of the rectum to the lymph nodes beside the internal iliac vein and in the hollow of the sacrum and (ii) lymphatics that pass over the seminal vesicles and follow the vas deferens for a short distance to drain into the external iliac lymph nodes. From retroperitoneal lymph nodes, the mediastinal nodes and occasionally the supraclavicular nodes may become implicated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Lymphatic spread is the most common mode of spread Option: B. Prostate cancer is the most common site of origin for skeletal metastasis Option: D. Lumbar vertebra, the pelvis is the most common site of bone metastasis

Extraedge:

The median survival of men with metastatic disease is about three years

questions.text: A 60year male presented with acute retention of urine; he has been a known smoker for 40 years. On examination abdomen is soft, bladder is palpable. Catheterization was done. Per rectal examination, show irregular hard enlarged prostate. Total Prostate-specific antigen - 1500ng/ml, Free PSA 5%. what is the next step of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TRUS guided biopsy Abnormal Dre, With Elevated Psa And Redeced Free Psa Is Highly Suggestive Of Malignancy, Hence Biopsy Has To Be Done

Highyeild:

Investigations : Rectal Examination mpMRI Prostatic Biopsy General Blood test and Liver Function Test Prostate Specific Antigen Cross-Sectional Imaging with MRI and Transrectal Ultrasound Bone Scan PSMA Prostatic Biopsy: If there is suspicion of prostate cancer, because of local findings, a raised PSA or metastatic disease, then a prostate biopsy using an automated gun under TRUS guidance is recommended This is usually performed transrectally, although increasingly the transperineal approach is being used. The broad-spectrum antibiotic cover is given to all patients to reduce the incidence of sepsis, which is greater with transrectal than with transperineal biopsy. Transperineal biopsy usually involves sedation or general anesthetic while transrectal biopsy can be performed under local anesthetic. Increasingly, areas appearing suspicious for prostate cancer on mpMRI can be targeted for biopsy to increase the diagnostic yield. TRUS scanning can also be used to stage prostate cancer. Locally extensive disease (T2) can be diagnosed with increased sensitivity by TRUS compared with the rectal examination, but many tumors will still be missed. This problem remains a real one in screening for early prostate cancer; In comparison with breast cancer, with mammography detecting 70–80% of tumors, TRUS plus rectal examination and measurement of PSA will detect only 30–50% of cancers that are known to be present on autopsy studies (although it may detect the larger, more signifcant cancers).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. MRI Is The Investigation Of Choice To Stage Ca Prostate strong>Option: C. CT Is Needed In Case Of Bone Metastasis

Extraedge:

Nowadays, fusion biopsy is becoming popular ; this is where mpMRI and TRUS images are fused with the help of software and a biopsy is taken very accurately from the index lesion.

questions.text: A 70-year- male complained of increased frequency of micturition, nocturia, and poor stream. known smoker for 30 years. On examination, the abdomen is with, no organomegaly, no tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. Per rectal examination, the prostate is irregular, hard, and nodular prostate. The Prostate-specific antigen is 500ng/ml. which of the following is not an indication of a bone scan?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T1 WITH PSA < 20ng/ml T1 WITH PSA > 20ng/ml IS THE INDICATION FOR BONE SCAN

Highyeild:

Once the diagnosis has been established, if the metastatic spread is suspected based (based on a high PSA [> ten ng/mL], locally advanced disease or presence of Gleason 7 or higher) a bone scan should be carried out. If, however, the PSA is <10 ng/mL, then a bone scan would be performed only on clinical indications. The bone scan is performed by injecting technetium-99m, which is then monitored using a gamma camera. It is more sensitive in the diagnosis of metastases than a skeletal survey, but false positives occur in areas of arthritis, osteomyelitis, or a healing fracture INDICATION FOR BONE SCAN CA PROSTATE T1 WITH PSA > 20ng/m T2 WITH PSA > 10ng/ml GLEASON SCORE > 7 T3/T4 SYMPTOMATIC OF BONE METASTASIS

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - INDICATION FOR BONE SCAN CA PROSTATE T1 WITH PSA > 20ng/m T2 WITH PSA > 10ng/ml GLEASON SCORE > 7 T3/T4 SYMPTOMATIC OF BONE METASTASIS

questions.text: A 70year male came with complaints of dribbling of urine, nocturia, and nocturnal incontinence. Known as a smoker for 30 years. On examination, the abdomen is soft, no organomegaly, no tenderness, guarding or rigidity. Per rectal examination, prostate is irregular, hard and nodular prostate. Prostate-specific antigen is 1500ng/ml, free PSA- 4%. TRUS-guided biopsy was done and confirmed it to be an adenocarcinoma of the prostate. MRI shows tumour invading seminal vesicles. What is the T stage for this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T3b T3b is tumour extends beyond the prostate into seminal vesicle

Highyeild:

T1a, T1b and T1c. These are incidentally found tumours in a clinically benign gland after histological examination of a prostatectomy specimen. T1a is a tumour involving less than 5% of the resected specimen; these tumours are usually well or moderately differentiated. T1b is a tumour involving >5% of the resected specimen. T1c tumours are impalpable tumours found following investigation of a raised PSA. T2a disease presents as a suspicious nodule on rectal examination that is confined within the prostate capsule and involves one lobe. T2b means that the cancer is in more than half of one side of the prostate gland, but not both sides. T2c means that the cancer is on both sides but is still inside the prostate gland. T3 tumour extends through the capsule: T3a, uni- or bilateral extension; T3b, seminal vesical extension. T4 is a tumour fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles – levator muscles, external sphincter, rectum or pelvic side wall.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. T2 Disease Presents As Suspicious Nodule On Rectal Examination Within Prostate Capsule Involving One/Both Lobe Option: C. T3A Tumour Extends Through The Capusle Option: D. Tumour Is Fixed Or Invading Adjacent Structure Other Than Seminal Vesicle

Extraedge:

This depends on the stage and grade of disease: T1 and T2 The progression rate of well-differentiated T1a prostate cancer is very low: 10-14% after 8 years. For moderately differentiated tumours, the rate is about 20%. For T1b and T2 tumours, the rate is in excess of 35% T3 and T4 (MO) About 50% progress to bony metastases after 3-5 years M1 The median survival of men with metastatic disease is about 3 years

questions.text: A 60year male presented with came with complaints of Increased frequency of micturition, nocturia, and nocturnal incontinence. . a known smoker for 30 years. Per rectal examination, the prostate is irregular, hard, and nodular prostate. Prostate-specific antigen is 500ng/ml, free PSA- 4%. TRUS-guided biopsy was done and confirmed it to be an adenocarcinoma of the prostate. MRI shows a tumor invading seminal vesicles. The patient is planned for a radical prostatectomy. Which of the following is the most common late complication of radical prostatectomy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Erectile dysfunction Erectile dysfunction Is the most common late complication of radical prostatectomy due to parasympathetic injury

Highyeild:

Prostatectomy : Approaches : Transurethrally (TURP) Retropubically(RPP) Through the bladder(transversally - TVP) From the perineum Transurethral Prostate Surgery : TURP remains the most commonly performed procedure for the surgical correction of BOO Strips of tissue are cut from the bladder neck down to the level of the verumontanum. Cutting is performed by a high-frequency diathermy current, which is applied across a loop mounted on the hand-held trigger of the resectoscope. Coagulation of bleeding points can be accurately achieved. The ‘chips’ of the prostate are then removed from the bladder using an Ellik evacuator. Resection proceeds at 1 g/minute in experienced hands Following TURP, careful hemostasis is performed, and a three-way, self-retaining catheter rinsed with isotonic saline is introduced into the bladder to prevent any further bleeding from forming blood clots. Irrigation is continued until the out of is pale pink, and the catheter is usually removed on the second or third postoperative day Complications : Local Haemorrhage Perforation of the bladder/prostatic capsule Sepsis Incontinence Retrograde ejaculation and Erectile dysfuntion Urethral Stricture Bladder neck contracture General Cardiovascular - Pulmonary atelectasis, pneumonia, myocardial infarction,congestive cardiac failure, and deep venous thrombosis Water Intoxication

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Haemorrhage is the most common early complication of radical prostatectomy Option: C. DVT is the most common cause of death following radical prostatectomy Option: D. Urethral stricture is not an complication of radical prostatectomy

questions.text: A 50year male presented with complaints of acute retention of urine and abdominal pain. On examination, the abdomen is distended, with hypogastric tenderness and palpable bladder. Catheterization done. Ultrasound shows benign prostatic hypertrophy. PSA-3ng/ml. the surgeon plans for TURP. While doing the procedure, he uses the instrument shown below. identify the instrument?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Elliks Evacuator During Turp Chips Of Prostate Is Removed Using Elliks Evacuator

Cutting is performed by a high-frequency diathermy current, which is applied across a loop mounted on the hand-held trigger of the resectoscope. Coagulation of bleeding points can be accurately achieved. The ‘chips’ of the prostate are then removed from the bladder using an Ellik evacuator. Resection proceeds at 1 g/minute in experienced hands Following TURP, careful hemostasis is performed, and a three-way, self-retaining catheter rinsed with isotonic saline is introduced into the bladder to prevent any further bleeding from forming blood clots. Irrigation is continued until the out of is pale pink, and the catheter is usually removed on the second or third postoperative day Complications : Local Haemorrhage Perforation of the bladder/prostatic capsule Sepsis Incontinence Retrograde ejaculation and Erectile dysfuntion Urethral Stricture Bladder neck contracture General Cardiovascular - Pulmonary atelectasis, pneumonia, myocardial infarction,congestive cardiac failure, and deep venous thrombosis Water Intoxication

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Collings Knife Is Used In Turp To Divided The Bladder Neck And Prostatic Urethra If Needed Option: C. Cystoscope- Thin Tube With Light And Camera Inserted Through Urethra To Visualize The Bladder

questions.text: A 50-year- male presented with complaints of dribbling of urine, nocturia, and nocturnal incontinence. a known smoker for 30 years. Per rectal examination, the prostate is irregular, hard and nodular prostate. The prostate-specific antigen is 500ng/ml, free PSA- 2%. TRUS-guided biopsy was done and confirmed it to be an adenocarcinoma of the prostate. MRI shows tumour invading seminal vesicles, no nodal involvement. What is the stage of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T3b N0 M0 T3b is a tumour that extends beyond the prostate into a seminal vesicle with no nodal or distant metastasis.

Highyeild:

T1a, T1b and T1c. These are incidentally found tumours in a clinically benign gland after histological examination of a prostatectomy specimen. T1a is a tumour involving less than 5% of the resected specimen; these tumours are usually well or moderately differentiated. T1b is a tumour involving >5% of the resected specimen. T1c tumours are impalpable tumours found following investigation of a raised PSA. T2a disease presents as a suspicious nodule on rectal examination that is confined within the prostate capsule and involves one lobe. T2b means that the cancer is in more than half of one side of the prostate gland, but not both sides. T2c means that the cancer is on both sides but is still inside the prostate gland. T3 tumour extends through the capsule: T3a, uni- or bilateral extension; T3b, seminal vesical extension. T4 is a tumour fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles – levator muscles, external sphincter, rectum or pelvic side wall.

Extraedge:

This depends on the stage and grade of disease: T1 and T2 The progression rate of well-differentiated T1a prostate cancer is very low: 10-14% after 8 years. For moderately differentiated tumours, the rate is about 20%. For T1b and T2 tumours, the rate is in excess of 35% T3 and T4 (MO) About 50% progress to bony metastases after 3-5 years M1 The median survival of men with metastatic disease is about 3 years

questions.text: A 60year male presented with came with complaints of increased frequency, nocturia, nocturnal incontinence, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. known smoker for 30 years. Per rectal examination, the prostate is irregular, hard, and nodular prostate. Prostate-specific antigen is 1500ng/ml, free PSA- 6%. TRUS-guided biopsy was done and confirmed it to be an adenocarcinoma of the prostate. MRI shows tumor invading seminal vesicles, no nodal involvement. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Radiotherapy followed by androgen blocking therapy

questions.correct_answer: D. Radiotherapy followed by androgen blocking therapy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radiotherapy followed by androgen blocking therapy Treatment For T3N0Mo – Radical Prostatectomy Followed By Androgen Blocking Therapy Or Radiotherapy Followed By Androgen Blocking Therapy Or Neoadjuvant Hormonal Therapy Followed By Radiotherapy

Highyeild:

Treatment in CA : Treatment options for prostate cancer depend on stage of disease, life expectancy of the patient and patient preference PSA, DRE and biopsy Gleason grade are used to predict pathological stage Localised cancers can be treated by radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy and active monitoring (surveillance) Treatment of advanced disease is palliative, and hormone ablation remains the frst-line therapy; once it starts failing, chemotherapy is used with short-term success

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Active surveillance is an option for T1 disease Option: B. Hormone therapy is given for T1b, T2a Option: C. Radical prostatectomy alone is a treatment for T2 disease

questions.text: A 60- year- old male presented with lower urinary tract symptoms of frequency and hesitancy of micturition. USG showed Grade III prostatomegaly. Where does the pathology arise from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transitional zone BPH arises from transitional zone

Highyeild:

Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia: Occurs in men over 50 years of age; by the age of 60 years, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH It is a common cause of signifcant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men and the most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men >70 years of age Pathology: BPH affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees. BPH typically affects the submucous group of glands in the transitional zone , forming a nodular enlargement. Effects / Consequences : No symptoms, no BOO No symptoms, but urodynamic evidence of BOO LUTS, no evidence of BOO LUTS and BOO Others (acute/chronic retention, haematuria, urinary infection and stone formation) Investigations : Essential investigations Urine analysis by dipstick for blood, leukocyte esterase, glucose and protein Urine culture for infection Serum creatinine Urinary fow rate and residual volume measurement Additional investigations PSA if indicated Pressure–fow studies Treatment : Conservative measures include watchful waiting in conjunction with fuid manipulation (avoid fuid binge and late night intake) and a reduction in caffeinated and alcoholic drinks Drug therapy is with α-blockers or, in men with a large prostate, a 5α-reductase inhibitor, or both; combination therapy has a better outcome in glands bigger than 35 g Interventional measures include transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which remains the gold standard ; consider HOLEP (holmium laser enucleation of the prostate), open/ robotic simple prostatectomy for large glands; new minimally invasive treatment options that are available to patients include prostate artery embolisation (PAE), water vapor prostate treatment, prostatic urethral lift (Urolift), and water jet treatment (Aquablation)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Carcinoma arises from peripheral zone Option B. Central zone is posterior to the urethral lumen and above ejaculatory duct

questions.text: On operating a patient with voiding LUTS For TURP, which is the fluid of choice for operating larger prostates with bipolar diathermy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NS Normal saline is an irrigational fluid of choice postoperatively and can be used in bipolar TURP. When used intraoperatively with monopolar, it dissociates and conducts current

Highyeild:

Prostatectomy : Approaches : Transurethrally (TURP) Retropubically(RPP) Through the bladder(transversally - TVP) From the perineum Transurethral Prostate Surgery : TURP remains the most commonly performed procedure for the surgical correction of BOO Strips of tissue are cut from the bladder neck down to the level of the verumontanum. Cutting is performed by a high-frequency diathermy current, which is applied across a loop mounted on the hand-held trigger of the resectoscope. Coagulation of bleeding points can be accurately achieved. The ‘chips’ of the prostate are then removed from the bladder using an Ellik evacuator. Resection proceeds at 1 g/minute in experienced hands Following TURP, careful hemostasis is performed, and a three-way, self-retaining catheter rinsed with isotonic saline is introduced into the bladder to prevent any further bleeding from forming blood clots. Irrigation is continued until the out of is pale pink, and the catheter is usually removed on the second or third postoperative day Complications : Local Haemorrhage Perforation of the bladder/prostatic capsule Sepsis Incontinence Retrograde ejaculation and Erectile dysfuntion Urethral Stricture Bladder neck contracture General Cardiovascular - Pulmonary atelectasis, pneumonia, myocardial infarction,congestive cardiac failure, and deep venous thrombosis Water Intoxication

questions.text: Gleason score: all are true except?

options.label: C
options.text: Higher the score, poorer the prognosis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scores range from 1-10

Highyeild:

The prostate is a glandular structure consisting of ducts and acini; thus, the histological pattern is one of an adenocarcinoma. A layer of myoepithelial cells surrounds the prostatic glands. The first change associated with carcinoma is the loss of the basement membrane, with glands appearing to be in confluence. As the cell type becomes less differentiated, more solid sheets of carcinoma cells are seen. A classification of the histological pattern based on the degree of glandular dedifferentiation and its relation to stroma has been devised by Gleason. Prostate cancers exhibit heterogeneity within the tissue, and so two histological areas of the prostate are each scored between 3 and 5. Grades 1 and 2 are now not reported as their outcome is similar to grade 3. Grade 3 cancers rarely metastasize . The scores are added to give an overall Gleason score of between 6 and 10; this (and the volume of cancer) appears to correlate well with the likelihood of spread and the prognosis

Extraedge:

Given by ISUP and WHO: Grade groups are as follows: Given by 1 = Gleason score 3 + 3 = 6 2 = Gleason score 3 + 4 = 7 3 = Gleason score 4 + 3 = 7 4 = Gleason score 8 (4 + 4 = 8, 3 + 5 = 8, 5 + 3 = 8) 5 = Gleason score ≥9 (4 + 5 = 9, 5 + 4 = 9, 5 + 5 = 10)

questions.text: During TURP, the surgeon takes care to dissect the verumontanum to prevent injury to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

External urethral sphincter The male urethra is a tubular structure extending from the bladder neck to the external urinary meatus at the tip of the glans penis. It has four components, named (from proximal to distal) the prostatic, membranous, bulbar, and penile urethra. The prostatic urethra extends from the bladder neck to the verumontanum and is compressed on either side by the lateral lobes of the prostate, giving it a slit-like configuration. The verumontanum is a small hillock of tissue indented at its crown by a pit called the utriculus masculine. It marks the proximal extent of the external urethral sphincter and is an important landmark for urologists performing transurethral resection of the prostate.

Highyeild:

Prostatectomy : Approaches : Transurethrally (TURP) Retropubically(RPP) Through the bladder(transversally - TVP) From the perineum Transurethral Prostate Surgery : TURP remains the most commonly performed procedure for the surgical correction of BOO Strips of tissue are cut from the bladder neck down to the level of the verumontanum. Cutting is performed by a high-frequency diathermy current, which is applied across a loop mounted on the hand-held trigger of the resectoscope. Coagulation of bleeding points can be accurately achieved. The ‘chips’ of the prostate are then removed from the bladder using an Ellik evacuator. Resection proceeds at 1 g/minute in experienced hands Following TURP, careful hemostasis is performed, and a three-way, self-retaining catheter rinsed with isotonic saline is introduced into the bladder to prevent any further bleeding from forming blood clots. Irrigation is continued until the out of is pale pink, and the catheter is usually removed on the second or third postoperative day Complications : Local Haemorrhage Perforation of the bladder/prostatic capsule Sepsis Incontinence Retrograde ejaculation and Erectile dysfuntion Urethral Stricture Bladder neck contracture General Cardiovascular - Pulmonary atelectasis, pneumonia, myocardial infarction,congestive cardiac failure, and deep venous thrombosis Water Intoxication
